8.verse: The battle spread over the entire countryside, and the forest claimed more victims that day than the sword.

9.verse: Death of Absalom. -Meanwhile, Absalom, by chance, happened to encounter some of David’s men. He was riding on his mule, and as it passed under the thick branches of a large oak, his head became caught in its branches, and he was left hanging in midair while the mule he had been riding continued on.

10.verse: Someone who had seen this reported to Joab: “I saw Absalom hanging from an oak.”

11.verse: Joab said to the man who had informed him: “If you actually saw him, why then did you not strike him to the ground then and there? I would have willingly given you ten pieces of silver and a belt.”

12.verse: However, the man replied to Joab: “Even if you were to weigh out a thousand shekels of silver and place them in the palm of my hand, I would not raise my hand against the king’s son. For in our hearing the king charged you and Abishai and Ittai: ‘Protect the young man Absalom for my sake.’

13.verse: On the other hand, if I had dealt treacherously with Absalom and thereby placed my life in jeopardy—and nothing is hidden from the king—then you would have dissociated yourself from me.”

14.verse: Joab then answered him bluntly: “I cannot waste my time arguing with you.” Thereupon he took three javelins in his hand and thrust them into the heart of Absalom while he was still alive, hanging in midair from the oak tree.

15.verse: Then ten young men who served as Joab’s armor-bearers closed in on Absalom, struck him, and killed him.

16.verse: After that, Joab ordered the trumpet to be sounded, and the soldiers ceased their pursuit of Israel because he had ordered them to halt.

17.verse: They picked up Absalom, flung his body into a large pit in the forest, and piled up a great mound of stones over him. Meanwhile all the Israelites had fled to their tents.

18.verse: During his lifetime Absalom had taken a pillar and erected it for himself in the King’s Valley, for he said: “I have no son to perpetuate the memory of my name.” He named the pillar after himself, and to the present day it is still called Absalom’s Monument.

19.verse: David Told of Absalom’s Death. -Then Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, said to Joab: “Grant me permission to take the good news to the king that the Lord has delivered him from the power of his enemies.”

20.verse: But Joab replied: “Today you would not be the bearer of good news. On some other day, you may do so, but you shall not do so today, because the king’s son is dead.”

21.verse: Then Joab said to an Ethiopian: “Go forth and report to the king what you have witnessed.” The Ethiopian bowed down before Joab and ran off.

22.verse: Then Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok, again said to Joab: “Come what may, allow me to run after the Ethiopian.”Joab replied: “My son, why do you wish to go? You will not receive any reward for the news you bring.”

23.verse: “Come what may,” he answered, “I want to run.” Joab finally relented, and he said: “I grant you leave to depart.” Then Ahimaaz sped off by way of the plain of the Jordan and outran the Ethiopian.

24.verse: While David was sitting between the inner and the outer wall, a sentry went up to the roof of the gate by the wall, and when he looked up, he saw a man running alone.

25.verse: The sentry called down to the king and reported this to him. “If he is alone,” said the king, “he has some news to tell us.”

26.verse: As the man continued to draw nearer, the sentry beheld another man running, and he shouted to the gatekeeper, saying: “Look! Here comes another man running alone.” The king asserted: “He must also be bringing good news.”

27.verse: The sentry added: “The first one runs just like Ahimaaz, the son of Zadok.” The king replied: “He is a good man, and I feel certain that he comes with good news to report.”

28.verse: Then Ahimaaz called out to the king: “All is well!” After that he prostrated himself before the king with his face to the ground and said: “Blessed be the Lord, your God, for he has delivered up the men who rebelled against my lord the king.”

29.verse: Thereupon the king asked: “Is all well with the young man Absalom?” Ahimaaz answered: “When the king’s servant Joab sent your servant forth, I was aware of a great commotion, but I do not know what it was all about.”

30.verse: The king said: “Stand off to the side and wait over there.” Therefore, he stepped aside and remained there.

31.verse: When the Ethiopian arrived, he said: “I bring good news for my lord the king. For the Lord has vindicated you this day, delivering you from the power of all those who rebelled against you.”

32.verse: Then the king asked the Ethiopian: “Has all gone well with the young man Absalom?” The Ethiopian answered: “May the enemies of my lord the king and all those who rise up to harm you share the fate of that young man.”

33.verse: Greatly shaken, the king went up to the chamber over the gate, weeping incessantly. And as he went, he cried out: “O my son Absalom! My son! My son Absalom! If only I had died instead of you, Absalom, my son, my son!”

1.verse: Chapter 19 -Joab Reproves David. -Word was brought to Joab: “The king is weeping and mourning for Absalom.”

2.verse: Therefore, that day’s victory was turned into one of mourning for the entire army when the troops heard the report: “The king is grieving for his son.”

3.verse: The troops stole furtively into the city that day, much as soldiers steal in who are ashamed when they flee from a battle.

4.verse: Meanwhile the king covered his face and cried out in a loud voice: “O my son Absalom! O Absalom, my son, my son!”

5.verse: Then Joab came to the king’s house and said to him: “Today you have caused all of your officers and servants to feel ashamed, humiliating those who saved your life today, and the lives of your sons and daughters, and the lives of your wives and concubines,

6.verse: by showing love for those who hate you and hatred for those who love you.“You have made it perfectly clear that your commanders and soldiers mean nothing to you. I feel certain that if Absalom were still alive and all the rest of us were dead, then you would be pleased.

7.verse: Therefore, get up, come out, and reassure your servants. I swear by the Lord that if you do not go out, not one man will be left with you by nightfall, and that will be worse for you than all the calamities you have endured from your youth until now.”

8.verse: On hearing these words, the king arose and took his seat at the gate. When it was announced to the troops: “The king is sitting at the gate,” they all assembled there before him.The Reconciliation. - Meanwhile all the Israelites had fled to their homes.

9.verse: However, throughout all the tribes of Israel, there was great dissension, and the people were arguing among themselves, saying: “The king delivered us from the clutches of our enemies and rescued us from the hands of the Philistines. But now he has fled from the country to escape from Absalom.

10.verse: However, Absalom, whom we anointed to reign over us, has fallen in battle. Why, then, does no one offer the suggestion that we should restore the king to his palace?”

11.verse: When King David learned of the debate that was ensuing throughout Israel, he sent this message to the priests Zadok and Abiathar: “Say to the elders of Judah: ‘Why should you be the last to bring back the king to his palace?

12.verse: You are my brothers, my own flesh and blood. Why then should you be the last to bring the king home?’

13.verse: “And say to Amasa: ‘Are you not my bone and my flesh? May God deal with me in the most severe way possible if from now on you are not the commander of my army in place of Joab.’ ”

14.verse: With those words, David won over the hearts of all the men of Judah as though they were one man, and they sent this message to the king: “Return, both you and all who serve you.”

15.verse: David and Shimei. -When the king on his return reached the Jordan, the men of Judah came to Gilgal to greet him and escort him across the river.

16.verse: Shimei, the son of Gera the Benjaminite, from Horonaim, hurried down with the men of Judah to welcome King David.

17.verse: Accompanying Shimei were one thousand men from Benjamin. Ziba, the servant of the house of Saul, together with his fifteen sons and twenty servants, hastened to the Jordan ahead of the king.

18.verse: They crossed at the ford to transport the king’s household and to do whatever the king requested.When Shimei, the son of Gera, crossed the Jordan, he threw himself down before the king,

19.verse: and he said: “I entreat my lord not to hold me guilty or to remember how shamefully I behaved on the day my lord the king departed from Jerusalem. I beg you not to hold my guilt against me.

20.verse: I humbly admit that I have sinned. Today I am the first of all the house of Joseph to come down to meet my lord the king.”

21.verse: However, Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, objected, saying: “Should not Shimei be put to death because he cursed the Lord’s anointed?”

22.verse: David replied: “Of what concern are my decisions to you, you sons of Zeruiah, that you have become my adversary? Should anyone be put to death this day in Israel? Am I not fully aware that today I am king of Israel?”

23.verse: Then the king said to Shimei: “You shall not die,” and he confirmed that with an oath.

24.verse: David and Meribbaal. -Meribbaal, the grandson of Saul, also came down to greet the king. He had not bathed his feet or trimmed his beard or washed his clothes from the day the king departed until the day he returned safely.

25.verse: When he came from Jerusalem to meet the king, the king asked him: “Why did you not go with me, Meribbaal?”

26.verse: He said: “My lord the king, my servant betrayed me. Since your servant is lame, I said to him: ‘Saddle a donkey for me so that I may ride on it and accompany the king.’

27.verse: “However, he has slandered your servant to my lord the king. But I well know that your majesty is like an angel of God. Do what you judge to be best.

28.verse: Although my father’s entire family deserved to die at your majesty’s hands, you placed me, your servant, among those who eat at your table. What right do I have to make any further appeals to the king?”

29.verse: However, the king said to him: “There is no necessity for you to say anything further. I have decided that you and Ziba shall divide the property equally.”

30.verse: Meribbaal replied to the king: “Let him take it all, inasmuch as my lord the king has arrived home safely.”

31.verse: David and Barzillai. -Barzillai the Gileadite had come down from Rogelim, and he accompanied the king to the Jordan, where he then planned to take leave of him.

32.verse: Barzillai was quite elderly, eighty years old. He was the one who had provided for the king during David’s stay at Mahanaim, for he was a very wealthy man.

33.verse: The king said to Barzillai: “Cross over with me and stay with me as my guest, and I will provide for you in Jerusalem.”

34.verse: But Barzillai replied to the king: “How many more years do I have to live, that I should go up with the king to Jerusalem?

35.verse: I am now eighty years old. Can I distinguish between what is pleasant and what is not? Can your servant taste what he eats or what he drinks? Can I still hear the voices of men and women singing? Why then should your servant be an added burden to my lord the king?

36.verse: “Your servant will go a short distance across the Jordan with the king. That hardly makes me worthy to receive such a generous reward.

37.verse: Please allow your servant to return to his own town and end his days there, near the graves of my father and my mother. But here is your servant Chimham. Let him cross over with my lord the king, and then do for him whatever you think is right.”

38.verse: The king replied: “Chimham shall cross over with me. I shall do for him whatever you wish, and whatever you request from me, I will do for you.”

39.verse: Thereupon all the people crossed the Jordan, and then the king also crossed over. After the king had kissed Barzillai and blessed him, Barzillai returned to his home.

40.verse: Then the king continued on his journey to Gilgal, accompanied by Chimham.Israel and Judah Quarrel. - All the people of Judah and half the people of Israel had escorted the king across the river.

41.verse: Before long, all the men of Israel came to the king and complained: “Why have our brothers, the men of Judah, stolen you away and joined with all David’s men in escorting the king and his household across the Jordan?”

42.verse: Then all the men of Judah replied to the men of Israel: “We did so because the king is our close relative. What right do you have to complain about this? Have we eaten anything at the king’s expense? Have we received any gifts from him?”

43.verse: The men of Israel retorted to the men of Judah: “We have ten shares in the king. In addition, we have a greater claim than you do. Why do you continue to slight us? Were we not the first ones to suggest the possibility of bringing back the king?” However, the words of the men of Judah were even more vitriolic than the words of the men of Israel.

1.verse: Chapter 20 -Sheba’s Rebellion. -A trouble-making scoundrel named Sheba, the son of Bichri and a Benjaminite, happened to be there. He sounded the trumpet and cried out:“We have no share in David,nor any portion in the son of Jesse.Every man to his tent, O Israel!”

2.verse: When they heard this, all the men of Israel deserted David to follow Sheba, the son of Bichri. However, the people of Judah maintained their loyalty to the king and followed him steadfastly all the way from the Jordan to Jerusalem.

3.verse: When David returned to his palace in Jerusalem, he took the ten concubines whom he had left behind to look after the palace, and he put them in a house under guard. He provided for them, but he did not engage in relations with them. They were shut up in confinement until the day of their death, living as if they were widows.

4.verse: Amasa’s Death. -Then the king said to Amasa: “Summon the men of Judah and order them to appear before me within three days.”

5.verse: Amasa set out to summon the men of Judah, but his mission took longer than the time specified by the king.

6.verse: Then David said to Abishai: “Sheba, son of Bichri, may very well prove to do greater damage to us than Absalom. Take your lord’s servants and pursue him before he can reach any fortified towns and escape from us.”

7.verse: Therefore, Joab’s forces, the Cherethites, the Pelethites, and all of the most skilled warriors marched out under the command of Abishai and left Jerusalem to pursue Sheba, son of Bichri.

8.verse: When they arrived at the large stone in Gibeon, Amasa came forth from the opposite direction to meet them. Joab was wearing his tunic, and over it was a belt with a sword in its sheath fastened at his waist. As he moved forward, the sword fell loose from his sheath.

9.verse: Then Joab said to Amasa: “I trust that you are well, my brother.” Having said that, Joab grasped Amasa’s beard with his right hand as if to kiss him.

10.verse: Amasa was not on his guard and failed to notice the sword in Joab’s left hand. Joab struck him with it in the belly so that his entrails poured forth to the ground. He did not find it necessary to strike a second blow, since Amasa had died instantaneously. Then Joab set forth with his brother Abishai in pursuit of Sheba, son of Bichri.

11.verse: One of Joab’s men stood on guard next to the body of Amasa, and he shouted: “Follow Joab, all those of you who favor Joab and support David!”

12.verse: Meanwhile Amasa lay wallowing in his blood in the middle of the road, and the man who had exhorted all of his fellow soldiers to follow Joab saw that everyone was stopping to stare at the body. Therefore, he carried Amasa’s body from the road and placed it in a field, with a garment covering the corpse.

13.verse: Once the body had been removed from the road, all the men moved on and followed Joab in pursuit of Sheba, son of Bichri.

14.verse: Joab Pursues Sheba. -Sheba passed through all the tribes of Israel until he arrived at Abel-beth-maacah. Shortly afterward, all of the Bichrites assembled and followed him into the town.

15.verse: Joab’s forces then arrived and besieged him in Abel-beth-maacah. After they threw up a siege ramp against the town, all of Joab’s forces began to batter the wall to throw it down.

16.verse: Suddenly a wise woman stood on the rampart and shouted from the town: “Listen! Listen! Tell Joab to come here so that I may speak with him.”

17.verse: When Joab approached her, the woman asked: “Are you Joab?” He answered: “I am.” She continued: “Listen to what your maidservant has to say.” He replied: “I am listening.”

18.verse: She then spoke as follows: “In the old days they used to say: ‘Go to Abel if you wish to find the answer,’ and in that way a matter would be settled.

19.verse: This town prides itself on being one of the most peaceful and loyal in Israel. She is like a faithful mother, and yet you are seeking to destroy her. Why do you seek to devour the inheritance of the Lord?”

20.verse: Joab replied: “Not at all! Far be it from me to devour or to destroy anything.

21.verse: That is not the case at all. However, a man from the hill country of Ephraim, named Sheba, son of Bichri, has rebelled against King David. If you surrender to us just this one man, I will withdraw from the town.” The woman said to Joab: “His head will be thrown over the wall to you.”

22.verse: Then the woman went to confer with all the people, and they followed her advice, cutting off the head of Sheba, son of Bichri, and throwing it to Joab. Thereupon he sounded the trumpet, and all of his forces withdrew from the town, each to his own home while Joab returned to the king in Jerusalem.

23.verse: David’s Officials. -Joab was the commander of the entire army in Israel. Benaiah, son of Jehoiada, was in command of the Cherethites and the Pelethites.

24.verse: Adoram was in charge of the forced labor. Jehoshaphat, son of Ahilud, was the recorder.

25.verse: Sheva was the secretary. Zadok and Abiathar were priests.

26.verse: Ira the Jairite was also David’s priest.

1.verse: Appendices -Chapter 21 -Gibeonite Vengeance. -During the reign of David there was a famine for three successive years. Therefore, David consulted the Lord, who said: “Saul and his family have incurred bloodguilt because he put the Gibeonites to death.”

2.verse: Thereupon the king summoned the Gibeonites and conferred with them. (Now the Gibeonites were not Israelites; rather they were a remnant of the Amorites. Although the Israelites had sworn to spare them, Saul had sought to exterminate them in his zeal for the people of Israel and Judah.)

3.verse: David said to the Gibeonites: “What can I do for you? How shall I atone for our treatment of you so that you may bless the heritage of the Lord?”

4.verse: The Gibeonites replied: “We have no right to demand silver or gold from Saul and his family, nor do we have the right to put anyone to death.” “Then what do you want me to do for you?” asked David.

5.verse: They said to the king: “We cannot forget that man who destroyed us and planned to annihilate us so that we would never be able to have a place in the territory of Israel.

6.verse: Please hand over to us seven of his male descendants, so that we may dismember them before the Lord at Gibeon on the mountain of the Lord.” The king replied: “I will hand them over to you.”

7.verse: However, the king spared Meribbaal, the son of Jonathan, son of Saul, because of the oath of the Lord that bound together David and Saul’s son Jonathan.

8.verse: But the king took Armoni and Meribbaal, the two sons that Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, had borne to Saul, and the five sons of Saul’s daughter Merab whom she had borne to Adriel, the son of Barzillai of Meholah.

9.verse: He surrendered them into the hands of the Gibeonites, who dismembered them on the mountain before the Lord. All seven of them perished together. They were put to death during the first days of the harvest, just as the barley harvest was beginning.

10.verse: Then Rizpah, the daughter of Aiah, took sackcloth and spread it out on a rock for herself, from the beginning of the harvest until the rain fell from the heavens upon the bodies. She kept the birds of the sky away from the bodies by day and the wild beasts by night.

11.verse: When David was informed about what Aiah’s daughter Rizpah, the concubine of Saul, had done,

12.verse: he went forth and took the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan from the people of Jabesh-gilead, who had absconded with them from the public square of Beth-shan, where the Philistines had hung them up after they had killed Saul on Gilboa.

13.verse: After David had removed from there the bones of Saul and the bones of his son Jonathan, he also gathered up the bones of those who had been slain and dismembered.

14.verse: The bones of Saul and his son Jonathan were buried at Zela, in the territory of Benjamin, in the tomb of Saul’s father Kish. After all of the king’s commands had been carried out, God answered prayers that were offered up on behalf of the country.

15.verse: Exploits in Philistine Wars. -Once again the Philistines went to war against Israel. David went down with his men to fight against the Philistines, but he began to grow weary.

16.verse: Ishbi-benob one of the descendants of the Rephaim, whose bronze spear weighed three hundred shekels and who was wielding new weapons, boasted that he would have no difficulty in slaying David.

17.verse: However, Abishai, the son of Zeruiah, came to David’s rescue, attacking the Philistine and slaying him. Then David’s men swore to him this oath: “Never again must you go forth with us to engage in battle, lest the lamp of Israel be extinguished.”

18.verse: After this, war again broke out with the Philistines in Gob. On that occasion, Sibbecai of Husha killed Saph, one of the Rephaim.

19.verse: Shortly afterward there was another battle with the Philistines at Gob, and Elhanan, the son of Jair from Bethlehem killed Goliath of Gath, the shaft of whose spear was like a weaver’s beam.

20.verse: There was yet another battle which took place at Gath, where a giant appeared with six fingers on each hand and six toes on each foot—twenty-four in all. He too was descended from the Rephaim.

21.verse: When he started to taunt Israel, Jonathan, the son of David’s brother Shimei, killed him.

22.verse: These four giants were descendants of the Rephaim in Gath, and they fell at the hands of David and his servants.

1.verse: Chapter 22 -Song of Thanksgiving. -David sang to the Lord the words of this song on the day when the Lord delivered him from the hands of all his enemies and from the hands of Saul.

2.verse: He sang:“The Lord is my rock,my fortress and my deliverer,my God, my rock in whom I take refuge.

3.verse: You are my shield and my saving strength,my stronghold and my refuge,my savior who delivers me from violence.

4.verse: I call upon the Lordwho is worthy of all praise;then I shall be saved from my enemies.

5.verse: The waves of death encompassed me,and the destructive torrents assailed me.

6.verse: The bonds of Sheol enmeshed me;the snares of death confronted me.

7.verse: In my distress I called out to the Lord;I called to my God for help.From his temple he heard my voice,and my cry to him reached his ears.

8.verse: “The earth quaked and shook;the foundations of the heavens trembled,quaking because of his blazing anger.

9.verse: Smoke rose from his nostrils,while a devouring fire poured forth from his mouththat kindled coals into flame.

10.verse: “He parted the heavens and came down;dark clouds lay under his feet.

11.verse: He descended on the back of a cherub and flew,soaring swiftly on the wings of the wind.

12.verse: “He used the darkness as his covering;dense thunderclouds were his canopy.

13.verse: From the radiance before himcoals were kindled into burning fire.

14.verse: “The Lord thundered from the heavens,and the Most High caused his voice to resound.

15.verse: He shot his arrows and scattered them;he hurled forth his lightning bolts and routed them.

16.verse: “Then the depths of the sea were exposed,and the earth’s foundations ware laid bare.This occurred at the rebuke of the Lord,at the blast of breath from his nostrils.

17.verse: “He reached down from on high and snatched me up;he drew me out of the watery depths.

18.verse: He delivered me from my mighty enemy,from my foes who were too powerful for me.

19.verse: “They confronted me in my hour of calamity,but the Lord came forward to support me.

20.verse: He set me free in a spacious field;he rescued me because he loves me.

21.verse: “The Lord has rewarded me for my righteousness;because my hands were pure he has recompensed me.

22.verse: For I have kept the ways of the Lordand have not followed the path of wickedness.

23.verse: “His laws are clearly known to me,and I have not failed to observe his decrees.

24.verse: I was blameless in his sight,and I kept myself free from sin.

25.verse: Therefore, the Lord has rewarded my righteousness,the cleanness of my hands in his sight.

26.verse: “To the faithful you show yourself faithful;to the blameless you show yourself blameless.

27.verse: To the pure you show yourself pure,but to the perverse you show yourself to be shrewd.

28.verse: Those who are humble you save,but you ignore those who are haughty.

29.verse: “You, O Lord, are my lamp;my God will enlighten my darkness.

30.verse: With your help I can storm a rampart;with my God to aid me I can scale any wall.

31.verse: The way of God is blameless;the Lord’s promise has proved true.He is a shield to allwho take refuge in him.

32.verse: “For who is God except the Lord?Who is a rock aside from our God?

33.verse: The God who girds me with strengthhas kept my feet free of obstacles.

34.verse: This God has made my feet swift as a deer’sand set me securely on the heights.

35.verse: He trains my hands for warso that my arms can bend a bow of bronze.

36.verse: “You have given me the shield of salvation;you stoop down to make me great.

37.verse: You broaden the path for my steps,and my feet have not slipped.

38.verse: “I pursued my enemies and destroyed them;I did not turn back until I made an end of them.

39.verse: I crushed them completely and they did not rise;they fell under my feet.

40.verse: “You girded me with strength for the battle;you subdued my assailants beneath me.

41.verse: You caused my enemies to retreat before me,and those who hated me I destroyed.

42.verse: “They cried out for help,but there was no one to save them.They cried out to the Lord,but he did not answer them.

43.verse: I ground them as fine as the dust of the earth;I trampled them down like dust in the streets.

44.verse: “You have delivered me from the strife of my people;you made me the head of the nations;a people I did not know became my subjects.

45.verse: Foreigners came forth cringing before me;as soon as they heard of me, they obeyed me.

46.verse: Having become disheartened,they came forth trembling from their strongholds.

47.verse: “The Lord lives! Blessed be my rock.Exalted be the God of my salvation

48.verse: O God, you granted me vengeanceand subjected entire nations to me.

49.verse: You freed me from my enemiesand exalted me above my adversaries,delivering me from violent men.

50.verse: “For this I will praise you among the nations, O Lord,and sing praise to your name.

51.verse: You have given great victories to your king,and you have shown steadfast love to your anointed,to David and his descendants forever.”

1.verse: Chapter 23 -The Last Words of David -These are the last words of David:“The oracle of David, the son of Jesse,the oracle of the man whom the Most High exalted,the anointed of the God of Jacoband the beloved of the Mighty One of Israel:

2.verse: “The Spirit of the Lord has spoken through me;his word is on my tongue.

3.verse: The God of Israel has spoken;the Rock of Israel has said of me:‘He who rules people justly,who rules in the fear of God

4.verse: is like the morning light at sunriseon a cloudless morning after rainfallthat causes the grass of the earth to sparkle.’

5.verse: “My house stands firm with God,for he has made an everlasting covenant with me,well ordered in all things and secure.Will he not bring to fruitionmy salvation and my every desire?

6.verse: “But the ungodly are all like thornsthat must be cast aside,for they cannot be grasped by the hand.

7.verse: No one dares to touch themexcept with an iron bar or the shaft of a spear,and then only to consume them by fire.”

8.verse: David’s Warriors. -These are the names of David’s warriors. Ishbaal, a Hachamonite, was the leader of the Three. It was he who brandished his spear over eight hundred men and slew all of them at one time.

9.verse: Next to him among the Three was Eleazar, the son of Dodo the Ahohite. He was with David at Pas-dammim when the Philistines had assembled there for battle. When the Israelites withdrew,

10.verse: he stood his ground and struck down the Philistines until his hand became so stiff that he was unable to release it from the sword. The Lord brought about a great victory that day. Afterward the people rallied around him, but only so that they might be able to strip the dead.

11.verse: Next to him was Shammah, the son of Agee the Hararite. The Philistines had gathered together at Lehi where there was a field with an abundant crop of lentils. When the Israelites fled upon being confronted by the Philistines,

12.verse: Shammah took his stand in the middle of the field, defended it, and cut down the Philistines. Thus the Lord brought about a great victory.

13.verse: At the beginning of the harvest, three of the Thirty went down to join David at the cave of Adullam, while a band of Philistines was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim.

14.verse: David was then in the stronghold, and there was a garrison of Philistines in Bethlehem.

15.verse: One day David said longingly: “Oh, if only someone would give me some water to drink from the well that is by the gate of Bethlehem!”

16.verse: On hearing this, the Three forced their way through the camp of the Philistines, drew water from the well by the gate of Bethlehem, and presented it to David. However, he refused to drink it, and instead, he poured it out to the Lord,

17.verse: saying: “The Lord forbid that I should do this. How can I drink the blood of the men who went forth to obtain it and thereby placed their lives at risk?” Therefore, he would not drink it.

18.verse: Abishai, the brother of Joab and the son of Zeruiah, was chief of the Thirty. It was he who brandished his spear over three hundred men whom he had killed.

19.verse: He was the most illustrious member of the Thirty and he became their commander. However, he never became one of the Three.

20.verse: Benaiah of Kabzeel was the son of Jehoiada and a valiant warrior who was renowned for many great exploits. It was he who slaughtered two of Moab’s most renowned warriors. On one occasion he also lowered himself into a pit and killed a lion on a day when snow had fallen.

21.verse: Further-more, he was the one who slew an Egyptian, a man of striking stature who was armed with a spear. Benaiah went against him with a club, wrested the spear from the Egyptian’s hand, and slew him with his own spear.

22.verse: Such exploits of Benaiah, the son of Jehoiada, won for him a name among the Thirty warriors.

23.verse: Although he commanded greater respect than the rest of the Thirty, he was not equal to the Three. David appointed him to be the commander of his bodyguard.

24.verse: Among the Thirty were Asahel, the brother of Joab; Elhanan, the son of Dodo, from Bethlehem;

25.verse: Shammah from Harod; Elika from Harod;

26.verse: Helez from Beth-pelet; Ira, the son of Ikkesh, from Tekoa;

27.verse: Abiezer from Anathoth; Mebunnai the Hushathite;

28.verse: Zalmon the Ahohite; Maharai from Netophah;

29.verse: Heled, the son of Baanah, from Netophah; Ittai, the son of Ribai, from Gibeah in Benjamin;

30.verse: Benaiah from Pira-thon; Hiddai from the torrents of Gaash;

31.verse: Ali-albon from Beth-arabah; Azmaveth from Bahurim;

32.verse: Eliahba from Shaalbon; the sons of Jashen;

33.verse: Jonathan, the son of Shammah, from Harar; Ahiam, the son of Sharar, from Harar;

34.verse: Eliphelet, the son of Abishai, from Bath-maacah; Eliam, the son of Ahithophel, from Gilo;

35.verse: Hezro from Carmel; Paarai the Arbite;

36.verse: Igal, the son of Nathan, from Zobah; Bani the Gadite;

37.verse: Zelek the Ammonite; Nahari from Beeroth, the armor-bearer of Joab, the son of Zeruiah;

38.verse: Ira the Ithrite; Gareb the Ithrite;

1.verse: Chapter 24 -Census of the People. -Once again the anger of the Lord was aroused against Israel, and he incited David against them, saying: “Go forth and take a census of Israel and Judah.”

2.verse: Therefore, the king said to Joab and to all the army commanders who were with him: “Go throughout all the tribes of Israel from Dan to Beer-sheba and take a census of the people so that I may know how many there are.”

3.verse: Joab said to the king in response: “May the Lord, your God, increase the number of your people a hundredfold, and may the eyes of my lord the king live to see it. But why does my lord the king want to undertake this task?”

4.verse: However, the king was determined to follow through on this enterprise, and he overruled Joab and the army commanders. Therefore, they departed from the presence of the king in order to take the census.

5.verse: After crossing the Jordan, they began at Aroer and the town in the middle of the valley, and then they moved on toward Gad and Jazer.

6.verse: After that, they proceeded to Gilead and to Kadesh in the land of the Hittites. Next they came to Dan, and from Dan they cut across to Sidon

7.verse: and arrived at the fortress of Tyre, moving on afterward to all the towns of the Hivites and Canaanites, and then to the Negeb of Judah, at Beer-sheba.

8.verse: Having traveled throughout the entire country, they returned to Jerusalem at the end of nine months and twenty days.

9.verse: Joab then reported to the king the number of those who had been recorded in the census. In Israel there were eight hundred thousand men who were fit for military service, and in Judah there were five hundred thousand.

10.verse: The Pestilence. -However, after the census had been taken, David was stricken with remorse, and he said to the Lord: “I have committed a grievous sin in what I have done. I beseech you, Lord, to forgive the guilt of your servant, for I have acted very foolishly.”

11.verse: When David arose the following morning, the word of the Lord had come to the prophet Gad, David’s seer, saying:

12.verse: “Go forth and say to David: ‘This is the word of the Lord: “I offer you three alternatives.” Choose one of them, and I will inflict it upon you.” ’ ”

13.verse: Therefore, Gad came to David and reported what the Lord had said. Then he asked him: “Which do you choose? Do you prefer three years of famine to afflict your land? Or do you prefer to take flight for three months while your enemies pursue you? Or do you prefer to have your land afflicted with three days of pestilence? Consider carefully the choices you have been offered and decide what answer I am to take back to the one who sent me.”

14.verse: David said to Gad: “I am in a desperate plight. It is far better to fall into the hands of the Lord, for his mercy is great. Let me not fall into the hands of men.”

15.verse: Therefore, David chose the option of the pestilence. Then the Lord sent a pestilence throughout Israel from that morning until the appointed time, and seventy thousand of the people died, from Dan to Beer-sheba.

16.verse: However, when the angel stretched forth his hand toward Jerusalem to destroy it, the Lord regretted the terrible calamity that he had approved, and he said to the angel who was afflicting the people: “That is enough! Stay your hand!” The angel of the Lord was then standing at the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.

17.verse: When David saw the angel who was striking down the people, he said to the Lord: “I was the one who sinned. I was the one who acted wickedly. What have these sheep done? Let your hand fall upon me and my family.”

18.verse: Sacrifice of Atonement. -On that day Gad came to David and said to him: “Go up and erect an altar to the Lord on the threshing floor of Araunah the Jebusite.”

19.verse: Therefore, David obeyed Gad’s instructions and went up as the Lord had commanded.

20.verse: When Araunah looked down and beheld the king and his retinue coming toward him, he went forth and prostrated himself before the king with his face to the ground.

21.verse: Then Araunah asked: “Why has my lord the king come to his servant?” David replied: “I have come to purchase the threshing floor from you in order to build an altar to the Lord so that the plague may be lifted from the people.”

22.verse: In reply, Araunah said to David: “I beseech my lord the king to take and offer up whatever he wishes. Here are the oxen for the burnt offering, as well as the threshing sledges and the yokes of the oxen for wood.

23.verse: All this, O king, Araunah gives to the king.” Then he added: “May the Lord, your God, look favorably upon your offering.”

24.verse: However, the king said to Araunah: “No. I insist on paying you for this. Under no circumstances will I offer up to the Lord, my God, burnt offerings that cost me nothing.” Therefore, David purchased the threshing floor and the oxen for fifty shekels of silver.

25.verse: Then David built there an altar to the Lord and offered burnt offerings and peace offerings. After this, the Lord answered David’s supplications for the land, and the plague was lifted from Israel.
